text: Supervised learning uses labeled data to train models for prediction.
label: machine-learning

text: Unsupervised learning finds hidden patterns or intrinsic structures in unlabeled data.
label: machine-learning

text: Reinforcement learning involves an agent that learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize a cumulative reward.
label: machine-learning

text: A neural network is a computational model inspired by the structure and function of biological neural networks.
label: machine-learning

text: Deep learning is a subset of machine learning based on artificial neural networks with representation learning.
label: machine-learning

text: A decision tree is a non-parametric supervised learning method used for classification and regression.
label: machine-learning

text: A random forest is an ensemble learning method that operates by constructing a multitude of decision trees at training time.
label: machine-learning

text: Support Vector Machines (SVM) are supervised learning models with associated learning algorithms that analyze data for classification and regression analysis.
label: machine-learning

text: K-means clustering is a method of vector quantization, originally from signal processing, that aims to partition n observations into k clusters.
label: machine-learning

text: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a statistical procedure that uses an orthogonal transformation to convert a set of observations of possibly correlated variables into a set of values of linearly uncorrelated variables called principal components.
label: machine-learning

text: Gradient descent is a first-order iterative optimization algorithm for finding a local minimum of a differentiable function.
label: machine-learning

text: Backpropagation is an algorithm used in artificial neural networks to calculate a gradient that is needed in the calculation of the weights to be used in the network.
label: machine-learning

text: A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a class of deep neural networks, most commonly applied to analyzing visual imagery.
label: machine-learning

text: A recurrent neural network (RNN) is a class of artificial neural networks where connections between nodes form a directed graph along a temporal sequence.
label: machine-learning

text: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are a type of RNN capable of learning long-term dependencies.
label: machine-learning

text: A Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) is a class of machine learning frameworks where two neural networks contest with each other in a game.
label: machine-learning

text: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a subfield of linguistics, computer science, and artificial intelligence concerned with the interactions between computers and human language.
label: machine-learning

text: A transformer model is a deep learning model that adopts the mechanism of self-attention, differentially weighting the significance of each part of the input data.
label: machine-learning

text: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is a transformer-based machine learning technique for natural language processing pre-training developed by Google.
label: machine-learning

text: GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) is a type of large language model that uses the transformer architecture.
label: machine-learning

text: Overfitting occurs when a machine learning model performs well on training data but not on unseen data.
label: machine-learning

text: Underfitting occurs when a machine learning model is too simple to capture the underlying structure of the data.
label: machine-learning

text: Cross-validation is a resampling procedure used to evaluate machine learning models on a limited data sample.
label: machine-learning

text: A hyperparameter is a parameter whose value is used to control the learning process.
label: machine-learning

text: Feature engineering is the process of using domain knowledge to extract features from raw data.
label: machine-learning

text: A confusion matrix is a table that is often used to describe the performance of a classification model on a set of test data for which the true values are known.
label: machine-learning

text: Accuracy is a metric that measures the proportion of correct predictions among the total number of cases processed.
label: machine-learning

text: Precision is a metric that quantifies the number of correct positive predictions made.
label: machine-learning

text: Recall (or sensitivity) is a metric that quantifies the number of correct positive predictions made out of all positive predictions that could have been made.
label: machine-learning

text: The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall.
label: machine-learning

text: The ROC curve is a graphical plot that illustrates the diagnostic ability of a binary classifier system as its discrimination threshold is varied.
label: machine-learning

text: The AUC (Area Under the ROC Curve) provides an aggregate measure of performance across all possible classification thresholds.
label: machine-learning

text: Linear regression is a linear approach to modeling the relationship between a scalar response and one or more explanatory variables.
label: machine-learning

text: Logistic regression is a statistical model that in its basic form uses a logistic function to model a binary dependent variable.
label: machine-learning

text: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) is a non-parametric method used for classification and regression.
label: machine-learning

text: Naive Bayes classifiers are a family of simple probabilistic classifiers based on applying Bayes' theorem with strong (naive) independence assumptions between the features.
label: machine-learning

text: Ensemble methods combine several machine learning techniques into one predictive model to decrease variance (bagging), bias (boosting), or improve predictions (stacking).
label: machine-learning

text: Bagging involves training a bunch of models in parallel on random subsets of the data.
label: machine-learning

text: Boosting involves training a sequence of models, where each model learns from the errors of the previous one.
label: machine-learning

text: Stacking involves training a new model to combine the predictions of several other models.
label: machine-learning

text: Dimensionality reduction is the process of reducing the number of random variables under consideration by obtaining a set of principal variables.
label: machine-learning

text: A perceptron is an algorithm for supervised learning of binary classifiers.
label: machine-learning

text: An activation function in a neural network defines the output of a node given an input or set of inputs.
label: machine-learning

text: The sigmoid function is a common activation function that squashes values between 0 and 1.
label: machine-learning

text: The ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) function is another common activation function that is computationally efficient.
label: machine-learning

text: A loss function (or cost function) is a function that maps an event or values of one or more variables onto a real number intuitively representing some 'cost' associated with the event.
label: machine-learning

text: The learning rate is a hyperparameter that controls how much we are adjusting the weights of our network with respect to the loss gradient.
label: machine-learning

text: A batch in machine learning is a subset of the training set that is used in one iteration of training.
label: machine-learning

text: An epoch is one complete pass through the entire training dataset.
label: machine-learning

text: A tensor is a generalization of vectors and matrices to potentially higher dimensions.
label: machine-learning

text: The bias-variance tradeoff is a central problem in supervised learning.

text: Variance is the amount that the estimate of the target function will change if different training data was used.

text: L2 regularization adds a penalty equal to the square of the magnitude of coefficients.

text: A feature is an individual measurable property or characteristic of a phenomenon being observed.

text: A label is the output variable that we are trying to predict.

text: Denormalization is the process of trying to improve the read performance of a database, at the expense of losing some write performance, by adding redundant data or by grouping data.

text: Database replication is the process of creating and managing duplicate copies of a database.

label: database

label: database

text: An index scan is a scan on an index.

text: A clustered index determines the physical order of data in a table.

text: A non-clustered index has a structure separate from the data rows.

text: A composite index is an index on multiple columns.

text: A unique index ensures that the indexed columns do not have duplicate values.

text: A database administrator (DBA) is a person responsible for the installation, configuration, upgrade, administration, monitoring, maintenance, and security of databases in an organization.
label: database

text: Data warehousing is the process of collecting and managing data from varied sources to provide meaningful business insights.
label: database

text: A data mart is a subset of a data warehouse and is usually oriented to a specific business line or team.
